Description: Solid-cast group-figure of the Osirian triad in copper alloy; funerary god Osiris stands in the centre of this triad, flanked by his wife, Isis on the right and his son Harpokrates (Horus the child) on the left, at back, bar connecting all three figures at shoulders’ height, with three suspension loops (possible amuletic function?), one broken off; simplistic and flat rendering; corroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), House of 'cache of bronzes'
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This piece was found with a large group of copper alloy finds in a house located to the south of the town (Petrie 1886, 41). The cache was probably made around the late 5th-early 4th c. BC, but some bronzes from this cache could be earlier in date (Masson 2015). This group-figure belongs to the type G30a in the typology of figure bronzes by K. Weiss and was already published (Weiss 2012, 351, 846, Nr. 1244, Pl. 60g). It is unique in the corpus of Naukratis. The very flat and crude design featured on this figure is found on other Naukratite bronzes, such as: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.247, 86.251, 86.253 and 86.284; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.616; Liverpool, World Museum 9,9,86,101.c; BM 1885,1101.568 and BM 1885,1101.91. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London, 41-42. Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten: Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
